text:
On tap during the brewerys third anniversary. The aroma wins with a distinct bourbon character of leather, caramel, chocolate, and a hint of dark cherry. 
No foam on the black 7oz pour. There was little lacing after sipping. A bit thin on the mouthfeel compared to others in the field. The alcohol is well blended with some heat on the back end, though I could not discern any coffee notes neither in the aroma nor in the taste,      which I find strange because the base beer is after all, Coffee and Cigarettes. The beer may have been taken over by the bourbon?

Draft at the brewery. Pours an opaque brown with a small dark tan that settles into just a bubbly ring eventually. Good gravy, this aroma is absolutely flawless- smooth, warming bourbon throughout, lightly charred oak, fresh roast coffee, chocolate, brown sugar, marshmallow, molasses, and very faint smoke. Medium-bodied, with low to moderate carbonation and a sweet, smoky, roasty, smooth, and subtly warming mouthfeel. This is stunning. Gorgeous in every sense. This was the first Cellarmaker beer I had out of the nights lineup and its safe to say Im fully on board with what theyre doing.

​On tap @ Cellarmaker. Black with a thin tan head. Holy smokes is there some coffee in this beer. A lot of sweet hazelnut, spicy and earthy coffee, and a hint of dried berries. Nice bourbon character, but its well integrated and not overpowering. Lots of graham cracker, vanilla, and dark chocolate. Really nicely done.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2016 The beer is black with a small brown head. Small amount of lacing. The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, light roast, light smoke, some oak. Taste is sweet with lots of fudgey chocolate. Barrel is still pretty light. Pretty big on vanilla. Some marshmallow. Full, round mouthfeel. Good stuff.

[1/27/16] Draught at Cellarmaker in San Francisco. Black. Great aroma full of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, and light smoke. Sweet flavor full of bourbon chocolate, vanilla, coffee, a bit of coconut, a smoky hint, and a bit of alcohol. Full-bodied. Great stuff.
Tap at the Brewpub. Black, flat. Nose is coffee, vanilla, bourbon. Smooth bourbon flavor, chocolate, coffee, light smoke only. Silky, oily palate. Great balance. Smooth and lovely.

Keg at Cellarmaker, 28/01/16.
Black with a small tan covering. 
Nose is big on coffee grinds, chocolate, dark malts, fruit cake.
Taste comprises brown sugar, coffee cake, molasses, subtle barrel, chocolate.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with light warming alcohol and subtle bourbon. 
Solid enough impy.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On tap at Cellarmaker. Poured black with thin tan head. Aroma sweet vanilla bourbon and smooth coffee pretzel. Light carb med bod. Taste similar to aroma loads of warm bourbon and sweet coffee. Very balanced. Killer
Draft - Coffee and chocolate and vanilla with some leather. Jet black with a dark brown head. Lots of Woody sweet barrel notes. Dark chocolate and some vanilla with a touch of coconut. Very nice.

"Cellarmaker" is a misnomer for a small-batch brewery that specializes in ultra-fresh hoppy beers, right? Nope. These guys do bourbon-barrel-aged better than most, if not all, of their competitors, including those distributed nationally. The next time youre drinking Founders KBS in the Bay Area, slap your forehead and exclaim: "I could have had an Imperial Coffee and Cigarettes!"

On draft at Cellarmaker. Pours an opaque dull black with beige head that steadily dissipates into bubbly lacing. Smells of chocolate, vanilla, ank oak up front with some coffee in the background. Tastes like it smells, but more coffee-forward, with some roast as well. Mouthfeel is full-bodied, slightly bitter and warming, and silky. Delicious!
On tap at the brewery. Pours black with small tan head that lasts. The aroma is roast, ash, cracker. Thick mouth, roast, chocoate, ash, cocoa, bitter finish. Very impressive

On tap at cellarmaker San Francisco. pours out black topped with a tan ring of a head. nose is great lots of heavy molasses roast malts chocolate lots of bourbon barrel vanilla. Taste is amazing coffee bourbon barrel vanilla brown sugar molasses. Very nice

On tap at the brewpub. Black pour with a few boozy brown bubbles. Aroma is super perfumy, tons and tons of bourbon, vanilla, rich cold pressed coffee, light smoke, roasty. Taste is quite rich, boozy, sweet vanilla, bourbon, cake. Palate is rich and silky. A tad cloying, nevertheless a very enjoyable monster of a beer.

Draught at Cellarmaker. Opaque black liquid with small tan head. Aroma of vanilla, light smoke, toffee, raw sugar, coffee, light chocolate and licorice. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of chocolate, coffee, light smoke, vanilla and raw sugar. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Awesome.
Draft at the source. A moderate coffee and might vanilla in the nose. Light smoke in the flavor with a hint of molasses. Light tar and tobacco. Really dang good.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2016 Yeah...
Dont even know where to start with this. Still somehow maintains that awesome coffee/smoke/smoothness/balance that both the base and base imperial versions have. Smooth as snot on a glass eye, and the bourbon is SO well integrated without overpowering or taking a back seat, adding vanilla, coconut and a hint of booze. Probably the best SF beer Ive ever had. 4.5+

On tap at Cellarmaker. Opaque jet black coloured pour with a lasting loose dark tan head. Aroma is insanely good, pungent vanilla, oak, smooth roast coffee, nice toasted coconut, cocoa, creme caramel. Flavour is composed of initially, sweet creme caramel, then ashy roast coffee, boozy Bourbon, little solvent. Palate is medium full, solvent, hot, moderate carbonation, semi sweet. Very impressed with this. Particularly the aroma .

On tap at the brewery. 
Aroma is rich with lots of dark chocolate and nice coffee notes. Light roast notes with lighter oak. Light bourbon as well. Coffee has a nice nuttiness to it. 
Pours an oily black with a small, thin, dark mocha head that lingers for a bit on the edges. Moderate legs and no lacing. 
Flavor is moderately sweet with a lot of dark chocolate notes. Lots of coffee notes with with a light nuttiness. Moderate bitterness. Light roast and smoke notes. A touch of ash. Lingering chocolate and coffee. Light oak and bourbon notes. 
Mouthfeel is full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a very delicious version of this beer. Nice chocolate and coffee notes with some light bourbon. Really nice.
